column4: hey, what the crap do i do with a deb package that tells me it can't install because i'm missing the dependency?
install the dependency ;)
don't install that thing
you don't even *have* that version of linux, assuming you're using breezy
apt-cache search ltmodem does show a few packages -- none of which is called "ltmodem" (they're actually the inux-restricted-modules packages), but i somehow suspect they contain that module
what do you mean by updated?
you're fine with the latest kernel. type "uname -r", if it's 2.6.12-10 then it's the current kernel for breezy
does "apt-cache search ltmodem" show anything at all for you?
you should see some linux-restricted-modules packages. is that what you see?
then install the one that best fits your processor. but i suspect it's already installed -- and if it is, it will already contain ltmodem
in other words -- if it's installed, then i don't quite know why ltmodem isn't working (never used it), but i can assure you that it will be installed
dpkg -l | grep restricted
you only care about "linux-restricted-modules-2.6.12-10-XXXX"
me neither. tried "sudo modprobe ltmodem"?
nevermind, that's not the correct name of the module
bah, "dpkg -L linux-restricted-modules-2.6.12-10-XXXX" will list you the contents of the package, but the funny thing is that i don't see anything resembling ltmodem there
depends on your keyboard layout.
i type it using altgr + the higher key left of Enter, followed by N. but that's because i have a swedish keyboard layout
let me guess, you deleted the files manually? =)
try "sudo apt-get --purge remove packagename", or "sudo apt-get --reinstall install packagename" followed by a purge
well you could try installing it with the "--force-depends" option of dpkg, and then remove it
don't think so... it should still bail out if it attempts to overwrite something
